title: GTX 980 TI EK Supremacy GPU Water Cooler mod
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
PERFORM AT YOUR OWN RISK!

EK Supremacy MX & Evo water cooler adapter to works on a MSI GTX 980 TI 6G Gaming and Gigabyte GTX 980 TI Xtreme Gaming.

Replacement mounting bracket for the EK Supremacy CPU water cooler. Have to take apart the cooler and replace the metal bracket with the printed one. Tested on a MSI GTX 980 TI 6G Gaming and Gigabyte GTX 980 TI Xtreme Gaming with GREAT initial results. Used heatsinks to cool the VRMS. Screws were borrowed from my Corsair redundant water cooler, but redesigning (or filing/cutting out) the bottom plate to house a bolt nut could be done to allows bolts to hold the cooler on.

Using Thermal Grizzly Conductonaut for testing. Initial temperatures decreased from 65C at 100% load on air to 45C on water (running on a triple radiator setup, fan on minimum fan speed). System has been running for more than 12 hours at a room at around 25-28*C.

author: TheDarkShadow

title: DIY HOTAS Frsky M7
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
After the 40 and 45 HOTAS I wanted some more changes so I designed a third version. :)

The biggest changes is the stick gimbals which are new ones (instead of old re-used). The performance and resolution will be much better due to ball bearings and hall sensors.

Parts box:
1pcs 3d printed box
1pcs 3d printed lid
2pcs 3d printed supports
6pcs 10x10x2mm neodymium magnets
6pcs M3x6mm (for box)
8pcs M3x8mm (for Frsky M7)
4pcs 2.2mm self-tapping screw (for numpad)
2pcs Frsky M7 gimbals: https://www.banggood.com/Frsky-Taranis-Q-X7-Radio-Transmitter-Part-2-PCS-Gimbal-M7-M7-High-Sensitivity-Hall-Sensor-Gimbal-p-1188845.html
8pcs Push buttons: https://www.ebay.com/itm/JK-Mini-Momentary-Push-Button-Switch-for-Model-Railway-Hobby-7mm-Pack-of-10-Red/282574315117
2pcs Turn knobs
2pcs Slide switches with 4 positions (DP4T): https://www.ebay.com/itm/10-Pcs-On-On-On-On-4-Position-DP4T-Slide-Switch-10-Pin-0-3A-50V-AC/121773448658
1pcs Numpad with 16 buttons: https://www.ebay.com/itm/4-x-4-Matrix-Array-16-Keys-4-4-Switch-Keypad-Keyboard-Module-for-Arduino/262977400014
1pcs USB-cable (A-connector and open ended), length depending on your need. For use with laptop I have only 60cm.
1pcs Rubber grommet suitable for USB cable
1pcs zip tie
1pcs BU0836A 12-Bit Joystick Controller: http://www.leobodnar.com/shop/index.php?main_page=product_info&cPath=94&products_id=219
1pcs BU0836A Break out Matrix board: http://www.leobodnar.com/shop/index.php?main_page=product_info&cPath=94&products_id=274
1pcs 3.3V LDO voltage regulator

Step 1. Print the box.

Step 2. Mount the knurl nuts in place using a solder iron. Make it hot and let it melt into the correct position.

Step 3 (optional). If you want to make the box nice spend some time to sand and plaster it smooth before applying paint.

Step 4. Glue magnets to box and supports. I use CA-glue with accelerator

Step 5. Insert a USB cable through the center hole of the box and solder to the BU0836. I use a rubber grommet to reduce dirt coming into the box.

Step 6. Solder USB cable to BU0836. IMPORTANT: Use a 3.3V LDO voltage regulator to lower the voltage since the Frsky M7 can only handle 3.3V. The BU836A is fine to run on 3.3V.

Step 7. Solder the numpad to the BU836A. Pads 1-4 to columns 1-4 and pads 5-8 to rows 1-4.

Step 8. Solder the BU0836 cards.

Step 9. Attach controls; joystick gimbals, numpad and pots to the lid.

Step 10. Solder cables to the controls, twist them to reduce interference and make sure they are just a bit longer then you need.

Step 11. Trim cables with some extra cm to spare if the BU0836 is on the center bottom of the box.

Step 12. Solder controls to the BU0836 cards. Take care to not use any connections already in use by the numpad. The following connections "should" be unoccupied: 5,6,11,12,17,18,23-36.

Step 13. Position BU0826 card in the bottom center of the box and pull on the USB cable so you have a few cm spare cm inside the box and attach the zip tie between the BU0826 and rubber grommet where it'll work as a strain relief.

Step 14. Hot glue the BU0836 cards (two dabs on either side so it is easy to detach if necessary).

Step 14. Use M3 screws and attach lid to box.

Step 15. Setup as a standard joystick in the simulator of your choice! :)

PS: You might benefit from calibrating the joystick in windows: https://www.howtogeek.com/241421/how-to-calibrate-your-gaming-controller-in-windows-10/

title: Sound Hole Preamp Mount for Fishman 301 presys in Camps M1S guitar

description.text:
I have a Camps M1S classical guitar. Since I wanted to mount a preamp to my guitar, I was not so willing to drill a big square hole on the guitar body. No! I would not sacrifise my guitar for this purpose. So the idea came for this purpose. I would still mount my Fishman Presys 301 preamp to the guitar. And it must have been on its sound hole!

This is still an continuing project.
1- One side of the mount should be taken off due to the fret location. I didnt do it on stl file. So i will do it later.
2- The guitar's acoustic sound was decreased due to closing the sound hole. So i need to open holes on the plastic in my next workshop. Hexagonal honeycomb geometry would seem sophisticated.
3-This mount fits very well on the guitar due to exact measurement. But it comes from sometimes while i am playing and touching the strings. I need to find a solution for that. A locker unit, a bolt or a mechanism that locks the preamp mount around the sound hole properly.

Note: So i drilled 2 holes in the guitar: 6.5mm output jack at the bottom of the guitar and tiny piezo hole under the saddle of guitar.

Enjoy music!

title: Reptile S800 Flight Controller holder
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
I designed this thing to hold a flight controller in the bay of a Reptile S800. I have not printed this thing as I modified the holder to also hold an OLED display.

https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2680791
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2699975

The base and screw towers are the same, so there should be no issues when printing.

Notes:

I have not printed this thing, but the settings should be the same as for my other FC holder. I printed those on my Prusa i3 Mk1 in PLA. My settings were:

Brim: 2
Material: 1.75 mm
Nozzle: 0.4
Layer height: 0.20
infill: 20% (though I used 10% on an earlier test print and it worked fine)
Bed temp: 50 C (70 C first layer)
Nozzle temp: 210 C (215 C first layer)
Speed: 40mm/s (60% first layer)
You will need to chase the threads with an M3 tap.
Designed in Autodesk Fusion 360

title: Bondtech BMG - Mosaic Palette Threaded Adapter Mount

description.text:
This is an adapter that allows you to attach the tube from the Palette's Scroll Wheel to the extruder on to a Bondtech BMG extruder. The tube connects with a threaded connector - a simpler and easier to use alternative to the hook & loop mounts supplied with the Palette.

The plate attaches over the front of the extruder so you will need 3 longer bolts. Also, the Bondtech label must be removed from the extruder - simply peel it off.

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

50%

No support needed, there is a separate support model that should be used. It will separate cleanly from the print if you use .2mm layers.

After building a prusa clone I found that the prints remained too hot and warped/melted and caused inconsistent and unreliable prints. After using a few printers with coolers, I figured the best way to improve my printer was to build this. As the one single thing I've changed with the printer, it has made the world of difference, turning a cheap clone printer into a reliable workhorse.

This blower sits against the print head, so I recommend ABS for better warpage resistance (air should be constantly flowing through it so it shouldn't melt).

12v 40mm fan
4 x 15-20mm length wood/plastic screws

author: SublimeLayers

description.text:
I could't find my 1/4" NPT tap and I didn't want to spend a ton on brass fittings so I threw together this quick 1/2" NPT to 1/4" NPT adapter.  I did it in OpenScad using the great "poor mans screw library".  Took about 10 minutes to throw together and 30 minutes to print on my MakerBot (w/ Acceleration).
By request - I uploaded the .scad after adding a few comments to it.  You will also need to download the screw library that this is a derivative of.  Note that the threads in this library are not tapered so technically it's not NPT.  At some point I might modify it again to add tapered threads but for now it works fine with teflon tape.

I printed this "strong" with 3 shells and 30% infill @ .3 mm layer height. 
Goal is for it to be water-tight in it's application.
The threads fit nice and tight...as is desired.
It seeped a tiny bit in application - so I took it off and gave it a very quick dip/wipe in acetone.  This sealed it up.  Don't over tighten!

title: replacement part for scuba box
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
So I have a scuba box (https://www.obi.at/aufbewahrungsboxen/mehrzweckbox-scuba-mit-deckel-xl-110-l-schwarz/p/4894986) that I bought at the hardware store to provide a moisture-free storage to my filament.

While I'm still quite pleased with the box I managed to break one of the polypropylene closures. So here's a replacement lock.

It behaves a bit different than the original one but it's more stable and easier to lock.

I made it in two parts because that way it's easier to print and it also fits the more common 20x20mm printers. However you need 2 pc. of M3 screws + nuts to keep the parts together. Material-wise I can recommend printing it in PETG with 100% infill.

author: JustinSpanier

description.text:
Remix of my original Ikea Gallant desk hanger. The legs are around 45mm in diameter.

This version prints as two parts: the strap that goes around the leg, and the peg which attaches.

I print the peg upright (hole up, flat side down) at 100% infill. Layer height up to you.

For the strap, you will need to use supports. I use 100% infill on this also for added durability.

The fit between the peg and the strap is really nice and snug. You may need to use a rubber mallet or something similar to fit them together.

Simply clicks onto leg, tighten with a zip tie.

This is a funnel for transferring contents of one Formlabs resin bottle to the other.

Use instructions:

  1. Remove top cap of bottle to be filled
  2. Place tool onto top of bottle to be filled
  3. Remove bite valve from bottle to be emptied
  4. Put bottle to be emptied in place in the slot
  5. Open top valve of bottle to be emptied
  6. When emptied, close all bottles and clean funnel out.

author: cookingfat

title: Rudolph the Red Nose Reindeer (Festive Flashing Fridge magnet)

description.text:
Print the parts as supplied.
Slot the Antlers into the head Slot.
Slot the head into the Shield.
Cut the legs of a 5mm Flashing LED to 3mm length and solder wires to them.
Feed the wires through the cable trunking from the nose end to the back battery port, slot the LED into Rudolph's nose.
Insert 2x LR41 batteries into the battery port and secure the wires to the battery.
Slot a 6mm magnet into the slot provided at back of the head part (behind the shield).
Place on fridge in cool position , whilst there check inside and help yourself to Xmas turkey or tiramasu with beer or chilled white wine...

Fractal-based volumetric object that resembles a bush. Available in the following versions:
RAW data 400x400x400 8-bit (zipped)
PNG codec AVI 400x400x400
PLY isosurface mesh 1420K polygons

This is from my series of volumetric objects created to help people explore the differences between polygonal and volumetric representations of objects. Learn more about the benefits of volume-based data structures for 3D printing here: 40westdesigns.com/blog/?p=371 Read more on the subject in my post on Engineering.com here: http://www.engineering.com/3DPrinting/3DPrintingArticles/ArticleID/4523/2012-The-Beginning-of-the-End-for-Polygons.aspx

title: IKEA Lack Leg Extension Bracket
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This part lets you extend the legs of IKEA Lack tables while letting you use the included threaded screws.

Note the orientation of the parts. FDM prints usually break along the layer, hence it is recommended to orient them as pictured.

I bought two used Lack Coffee Tables (90x55x45cm) as well as a Lack Side Table (55x55x45). The idea is to cannibalize the side table and use the legs to lift up one of the coffee tables.

This is an ongoing project, but here is my plan:

  1. Drill a smaller guide hole under a leg to screw-in another leg using the stock threaded screws. These screws are quite robust by themselves. Leave ~5mm room for the part to slip in snugly.
  2. Slip in the printed part and use 6x M3 (length TBD) screws with washer per leg. This step needs some preparation: mark the location of the M3 screws on the legs using a pen or marker and drill some smaller guide holes for the M3 screws to go in.

author: mortenkal

title: Angled Dry Box Feeder with Source
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Inspired by the design of sarman_1998 I created my own version which can be used in combination with PC4-M6 fitting PTFE tubing (6mm thread), and 2 M3 bolts + hexagon nuts.

The code can be changed to choose your own degree (or place a comment, and I will add a stl)

Items I used:
bolts: M3x10 DIN 7985 (cross) -> as long as it is flat at the side of the thread
washers: DIN9021 3,2mm washer (optional)
nuts: M3 DIN 985 (nylon locking nut) -> outside measures: 5.5 mm (parallel sides of hex), height 4.0 mm (2.4mm hexagon)

I decided to place the center of the holes at a fixed distance of 15mm from the tube-hole (so 30mm between both holes) to make it easy possible to replace them - if I need to do - for another design as long I keep using the same distance.

Printer:

PrimaCreator P120 v3 (Malyan M200)

title: Light Bar for Ender 2, and switch

description.text:
Updated thanks to an error found by jbidinger, thank you!.
the pulley wheel must be mounted to rear of the X-gantry to have full movement of X carriage. As such I made a new version c which has a cut away for the mounting plate on the rear.

Here is a light bar you can mount to the rear of your X gantry with 2 T slot nuts and screws.

I used this light roll: http://a.co/2jMP1eH

cut at smallest interval that is indicated on the roll. You will have a lot left over that you can use with any 12V source.

I then wired it to the rear of the Power Supply, positive lead goes to the V+ lug and negative to the COM.

I added a switch in the middle that I screwed to the side of my control box.
I am including my files to the switch.
I used this part:
5pc OLS 12V DC 30A 3-Pin SPST LED On/Off Rocker Switches - BLUE
http://a.co/i9y5ln0

or you can print this control box with built in switch placement:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2706488

If you make one please let me know, and post your photos.

description.text:
A filter I made for when I'm cleaning my aquarium. A hose (17mm) is inserted in the filter and while the water is drained from the aquarium I'm stirring up the gravel in the bottom and let the sludge be sucked up and out.
Secondly when fresh water is refilled into the aquarium via the hose the filter helps disperse the water stream.

The included STL file fits a hose with a diameter of 17mm but I've included a Fusion 360 design file for anyone who want to tinker with sizes and dimensions..

author: YOBSN

description.text:
I want to make another gun (https://youtu.be/kzh-1hUooik), but instead of making the "difficult parts" in wood, I choose to convert them into 3D printed parts.

28 jan 2018: Tried the assembly today. It works! Some improvements though and update of allmost all parts.

  1. Most important: Pins in BasePlate and TopPlate alongside the rotor have to be removed.
    Another attention point: have a strong band on the Cock, it has to bang the Slider hard in order to release a rubber band from the Rotor through the Rocker (maybe make the rubber band between Rocker and Reloadlever pretty loose?)
  2. Added an additional lip behind the Cock such to connect the rubberband to pulling the Trigger backwards
    Next up: make the rifle to mount this block into ;)

The idea is to embed them into a wooden body lateron. So no proof all is OK in the real world. Inventor does agree though and moves all parts as they should.

Ah... a remark from my son already: one pin too much in baseplate. Rubberband will be difficult from Rocker to Reloadlever. (28 jan 2018: no worries here! It just works!)

I plan to use M3 screws to hold top and bottom plates together.
My printer build surface was too small to fit on those plates, so I chopped both up into 2 pieces. Plates are available as one piece, but also the splitted parts.

Don't hesitate to comment!

print_settings.Notes:: Printed in ABS to allow use of glue to assemble the Laser Holder component.

description.text:
Wanted to try a couple of larger lasers on my Atlas 3D (FreeLSS) scannner.

Also saw a great idea on the web to use the tie rod turnbuckles from a model car to assist in precise adjustment of the lasers.

This is the resulting components from that update along with the SCAD source file.

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.4mm Nozzle

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Print one each of the parts labeled A or B
Parts with the last letter "n" use 3mm screws for the turnbuckle the other parts use threaded inserts.

Used some threaded inserts to hold the tie rods to the arms so the holes are pretty large. These should be reduced in diameter if you choose to use cap screws and nuts.

Lasers used were Model SYD1230 (have focus adjustments) - Laser Mounts include focus locking features.

Tie rods were from Banggood - SKU707772-3SHD0

Printed in ABS to allow use of glue to assemble the Laser Holder component.

As can be seen in the exported picture I used OpenSCAD to draw the center target dot that represents the center of the Atlas 3D turn table. This was then used to center the adjustment limits of the turnbuckles by selecting the best angle for the Laser holder arm connections.

This is designed to adapt to the manufactured frame for the Atlas 3D and replaces the mid plate with one printed that has the turnbuckle mount added.

print_settings.Notes:: Design/Modification:

description.text:
A nice sturdy and functional earbud case which doubles as a phone stand when open. To wind the cord up, shut the case and spin the disk on the top.

I designed this based on an old case for some cheap $9 earphones I got a while back. I loved how the case worked, but it was pretty cheap and only fit those particular earphones (which fell apart before the case did). I also figured that if I'm going to be carrying around a lump of plastic in my pocket, it might as well also serve as a phone stand.

This is still a bit of a work in progress, I'm still tweaking the design here and there. Please, by all means try it out yourself and let me know what your experience is in the comments! ^_^

Printer Brand:

LulzBot

Printer:

TAZ 5

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

20

Notes:

Some parts I used 100% infill but 20% works just fine. In particular, the Shell Top and the Hinge Pins should be printed at 100% infill (for strength and weight balance reasons).

Snapping Pieces Special Note:
The Hinge Pins were also designed to be printed on their sides to keep them strong in the direction the hinge forces are applied to them. Most of the pieces do not require any work after printing, but any of the pieces that require snapping together will likely need to be cleaned up to remove any excess material between the parts which may prevent them from flexing properly.

Assembly Instructions:

  1. Sandwich the Shell Top between the Spinner Top and Bottom before snapping the Spinner Top and Bottom Together.
  2. Fit the Shell Top and Bottom together and snap closed before inserting the Hinge Pins. If they do not fit, they may need to be cleaned up and sanded a little bit.
  3. Snap the Spool into the Shell Bottom.

I seriously assembled this without tools in the back of a courtroom waiting to be selected for jury duty. It's pretty easy. That being said, sand paper, a utility knife, and needle nose pliers helps a lot.

Design/Modification:
I designed the model in Sketchup and have included the file should anyone want to modify the design. Additionally, if you have any question as to how this should be assembled, then refer to this file for placement.

title: Lamp Holder for Hampton Bay Counter Rotating Pilot Ceiling Fan

description.text:
The Hampton Bay "Pilot" ceiling fan is shipped with a single Halogen light in the light kit. This is unpleasing in several ways. The light bulb is visible through the frosted glass. The light fixture generates heat. The light fixture will consume bulbs.

This print allows replacing the Halogen bulb with three LED bulbs. I used SIMBA LED E11 8W 120V 3000K Dimmable bulbs obtained from Amazon. You will also need extra E11 sockets. I obtained these from Amazon as well, as none of the local stores had E11 (they are not "candelabra").

I cut the connectors on the supplied fixture off, and soldered all three LED sockets in parallel. This is 120V, so use good heat shrink, etc.

The result is a pleasant, cool (physically cool, the LEDs are warm color temperature) light that shows three symmetric patterns through the frosted glass.

comments.author: MecannibalVector

title: Hictop 3DP-11-ATL Mini Differential IR Sensor Mount

description.text:
I am wanting to print on glass so the stock inductive sensor that comes with a Hictop-3DP-11-ATL printer will not work on glass. I did some research and settled on the mini differential IR sensor (https://miscsolutions.wordpress.com/mini-height-sensor-board/).

I created a sensor mount for it that replaces the inductive sensor mount and allows for adjustability up and down.

I am also including my Marlin 1.1.5 Configuration.h file so you can see how to set up the sensor in the Marlin firmware. Setting up the sensor is a bit tricky as most of the documentation for the sensor is for delta printers.

Here is some communication that I received from the sensor creator that helped me know what to do to change the firmware.

If you already had a different proximity sensor working, then you would need to:

  1. Connect the IR sensor in place of the previous proximity sensor - except that your old proximity sensor may have needed a 12V supply; whereas the IR sensor needs only 3.3V or 5V, which is available from the 3rd pin of the endstop connector on most controller electronics.

  2. In the firmware for your controller electronics, make sure that the pullup resistor on the input that the sensor is connected is enabled. Then the LED on the sensor should flash twice a few seconds after power up. If it flashes 4 times, then the pullup resistor is not enabled.

  3. The IR sensor produces an active high output. If your previous proximity sensor had an active low output (e.g. NPN inductive sensor), then you will need to invert the sense of the Z probe input, which is another firmware configuration setting.

  4. Measure the trigger height and configure that value in your firmware.

The sensor works like a charm now and I can print on glass.

Update
I tried out the mini differential IR sensor with the sensor in the same location as the inductive sensor and after several prints, I wanted to get the sensor closer to the extruder so I had more accuracy and could use more of my print bed.

I modified the IR Sensor Mount v1.stl and created a new mount that brings the IR sensor underneath the extruder motor and fairly close to the extruder. I haven't tried printing yet and hope the extruder doesn't get my mounting bracket/sensor to hot, but it looks like this will work better.

Update
After using the "IR Sensor Mount Under Extruder Motor v1.stl" part for a bit, it really started to warp. It was a touch to close to the extruder and I printed in PLA. I created "IR Sensor Mount Under Extruder Motor v2.stl" that stiffens the mount a bit, moves it a touch further away from the extruder, and is now printed in ABS. I am just getting ready to test it out, but from an installation standpoint, it is much better now.

description.text: I have included a 2D and 3D model of a pokeball. I have also included the colored files .x3d and .vrml (.wrl). The 3D model is 30 mm by 30 mm by 30 mm, and the 2D model is 30 mm by 30 mm by 1 mm.

Well, I managed to damage my original carriage handwheel so was forced to get a replacement sorted out.
This is the result.
The lathe is a chinese 7x14 as supplied by amadeal(UK), but similar lathes are supplied under many different names and by many different companies.
The diameter is 80mm, same as the original. It fits an 8mm shaft.
The original handwheel had a metal insert, which was locked onto the indented shaft with a grub screw.
This replacement is a tight fit onto the shaft, which is a good thing, and at present I have used a 4mm cap screw to secure onto the shaft, this had the advantage of using the full length of the threaded hole for strength, and in conjunction with the friction between shaft and handwheel, provides a solid feel.
The locking hole is not supplied with any thread, just a hole that will require tapping to your chosen size.
The handle was re-used from the original handwheel. This hole also required tapping and the thread on mine was found to be 6mm coarse.
At present it works well, and has been in use for a couple of weeks now, a future project will perhaps be to purchase or make a metal handwheel, but that won't be for a while yet...hopefully.
Just mind and use sufficient wall thickness tor the necessary threads. Think I used 3mm wall thickness, 20% infill.
The Sketch-up file is included in case there is any tweaking required to fit your application.

title: Wall Mount Drawbot
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Wall-Mounted Drawbot/Cartesian Robot

I designed this after seeing other drawbots and wanting something I could hang on the wall and create large scale prints with. It can be run from many different controllers but I am using a Arduino with a CNC Shield and a grbl fork with servo support much like the other drawbots and many of the grbl settings are similar. I am planning on replacing the arduino and shield with a duet board for better results.

https://github.com/robottini/grbl-servo

I printed most parts in PETG 100% infill with 0.20 layer heights and supports where needed. This uses V-slot rail and wheels from Openbuilds.

http://openbuildspartstore.com/v-slot-linear-rail-1/
http://openbuildspartstore.com/xtreme-mini-v-wheel-kit/

The Y Axis is 20x40 and the X Axis is 20x20. The belts are all run through the rail channels and it even has placement to hide the stepper wires and run a strip of LEDS along either axis.

I used a sg90 servo to move the pen and these steppers.

https://www.amazon.com/Stepper-Motor-Bipolar-64oz-Printer/dp/B00PNEQI7W

Using 24V and good quality stepper drivers is really necessary for the motor torque to pull the carriages along and I have used direct cooling on the board and heatsinks to keep the motors cooler. Bolt sizes vary from m3 to m5 at all different lengths but are primarily flat head or hex, sorry I will write up a parts list very soon.

Quality and speed are all very good. I have attached a image of a space filing curve my 1000x1000mm machine did at decent speed. I am sure this deserves a better write-up than I am giving at the moment but I will do a more detailed one in the near future. Last photo is a sketch of "Substrate" by Jared Tarbell on 22"x28" poster board.

Parts Marked XL space the machine farther from the wall to fit most thin stretched canvases.
Some of the parts need to be rotated before printing I will fix in the next upload.

description.text:
These are the 3d printed parts for my fork of the Printrbot community dual extrusion project. Instructions and full BOM are posted on the forum, linked here: http://forum.monstercafe.net/

Just a quick note, the bowden couplers are not my design, and are originally from user "daGHIZmo", here: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:596525

Also, for the Y-Adapter, ignore the zip-ties. That was my original test rig solution, but I have yet to change them.

comments.text: Hi, I really like this design and I'd like to set it up on my own PB Simple. I'm not entirely clear on how your extruders are assembles behind the spools. Are there any more pictures showing that?
comments.author: billix0

comments.text: It will probably make a lot more sense if I explain it. The metal handle is flipped around backwards, and then a small hole just big enough for a zip tie is drilled right on the end. The "motor mount" print slides on past the hole, then a zip tie placed through the hole, then the mount can't fall back off. Once the mount is on, you can slide the motors through the back, and then screw the extruder parts on from the front. Better picture here:
comments.author: billix0

comments.text: Ok now I get it. One other question. One on of your extruders, the lower half is printed. Obviously this is because the original piece is still on the print arm, mating the hot end to the bowden tube. Is there an STL available for that piece? I don't see it in the list of files on this Thingiverse item.
comments.author: Simulatedbog545

comments.text: You can print out Printrbot's alu-extruder found https://www.youmagine.com/designs/printrbot-alu-extruder, or you can buy a metal one from printrbot directly.

description.text:
This is my MiniQuad X-120 frame.
It's a true X frame and uses the 8520 brushed motors.
It should fit most of the tiny AIO cameras and brushed flight controllers.

The camera mount is designed so you can change the angle to suit your flying level/style.

You will need:
4 x 15mm standoffs or spacers to join the top and bottom parts.
2 x 3mm threaded inserts for the adjustable camera mount.
Double side mounting foam or hot glue for the flight controller.
Elastic band or hot glue for the receiver.
Elastic band for the battery.
Electrical tape to give the motors a snug fit in the arms if needed.

UPDATES:

31/12/2017 - Added a new Camera mount with a slot for cameras with lower cables allowing the cable to pass through the mount and the camera to sit better. Might need supports depending on how good your printer is.

1/1/2018 - Found that the arms can break when hitting hard objects just right (my bad flying lol) so modified where the arms join the body and added another web.

----------

Don't have a 3d printer? You can purchase this model from my Etsy shop.
https://www.etsy.com/au/listing/564737076/3d-printed-mini-quadcopter-drone-frame?utm_medium=SellerListingTools&utm_campaign=Share&utm_source=Raw&share_time=1512802982000&utm_term=so.slt

Designing takes time and resources, if you like and use my designs, please consider supporting me. Your support means a lot to any designer and encourages updates and new designs to be shared with the community.
https://www.paypal.me/pjlocko/3

Printer:

Tevo Tarantula

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

30

Notes:

Material: PLA
Temp: 205
Cooling: Yes
I use 30% infill but most parts are too thin for infill anyway
Layer Height: 0.2
Boundary layers: 4
Speed: 55 works well for my printer

Glass bed with gluestick for adhesion.

Depending on your slicing software, you may have rotate the top and bottom plates so you can print them upside down - see attached photo.

Notes:

Another way to get the motors to fit tightly in the mounts is to carefully warm the ends of the motor mounts with a heat gun and close the gap so the motor has lots more friction holding it.

print_settings.Notes:: To print these you want to use a large layer height (0.3 or more) and a width of 0.5mm. You will only print a single perimeter, no infill and no top or bottom layers. If you have an option for spiral mode printing this would be the time to use it. You can also turn off retraction if your machine has a fast layer change to make it a single continuous perimeter without stopping. I used CA glue to connect the segments together. To do this is squirted a puddle of CA glue onto a piece of glass and then rubbed the ends in it before clamping the sections together. Once glued they were very strong and never came apart (make sure the ends are smooth).

title: WS2811 Warp Core LED Diffuser for High Resolution 1701-D Warpcore

description.text:
Remixed Warp Core diffusers to fit WS2811 LED's.

I used these ones: https://www.amazon.co.uk/gp/product/B00JR0MJIU/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o03_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

Ignore the zits on my grey pieces, I printed with the wrong profile for my printer but they sit inside the warp chamber and cant be seen, so no big deal!

The files for the rest of the Warp Core can be found here: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2008591

Printer:

Creality CR-10

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Read

Infill:

Read

Notes:

I Printed the center caps with 10% infill and 6 bottom and top layers

For the rest of the diffusers:

To print these you want to use a large layer height (0.3 or more) and a width of 0.5mm. You will only print a single perimeter, no infill and no top or bottom layers. If you have an option for spiral mode printing this would be the time to use it. You can also turn off retraction if your machine has a fast layer change to make it a single continuous perimeter without stopping. I used CA glue to connect the segments together. To do this is squirted a puddle of CA glue onto a piece of glass and then rubbed the ends in it before clamping the sections together. Once glued they were very strong and never came apart (make sure the ends are smooth).

The LED strips should fit tightly into the groove provided.

For the center piece caps, you glue one cap on each end, like in the photo. I chose to make it a solid object to help stop the blue from bleeding into the center and the center lights from bleeding into the blue.

description.text:
This is an r/c hovercraft that I designed to be relatively easy to print and assemble, as well as needing no glue for assembly. It only requires a few small screws and pieces of hardware available at any good hardware store, and of course the electronics will also be needed. The design is modular to allow the repair of only certain parts of the craft should damage occur. Some basic tools will also be needed for assembly (any self respecting 3d printing guru should have the tools necessary).

The size of the upper hull (largest part) is small enough to fit on a 300mm build plate, so larger printers should have no problem printing. If you have a smaller printer you may have to cut and print in sections. Everything should be printed in the orientations shown in the photos, .3mm layer height for all works well. Use supports on all but the lower hull, skirt ring and skirt clips.

As you can see from the photos I have flown it quite a bit to test out it's capabilities and strength. I've flipped it a few times on pavement, rolled it a dozen or so and have run into many hard objects at a reasonable speed without sustaining major damage (a few scratches and dings so far), but a solid hit at full speed is likely to do a bit more damage. The skirt has been worn down after driving a dozen packs on very rough pavement, but still definitely usable. A sewn ripstop nylon skirt would be prefered and templates may be added in the future. Otherwise it performs very well and has plenty of control (even if using only two rudders), as well as tons of power. I have yet to get it up to full speed, but it definitely moves! Run time is about 5-7 minutes with the 1500mAh battery at full hover.

I still need to make the cover for the electronics, so that will be added soon. Thanks for looking, more updates to come!

Short overview and basic assembly video. https://youtu.be/FuvmvP_xeic
Here's a short clip of it cruising around a small parking lot. https://youtu.be/SpGD2eGdmpg

Parts List:

  • 2x 2205-2300kv Brushless motors (any brand will do, just confirm mounting hole spacing is 16x19mm)
  • 8x 10mm Motor mounting screws (ones that come with the motors may be too short)
  • 2x 20A Brushless ESCs (make sure only one has a BEC to eliminate the need for a reciever battery)
  • 1x 9g Steering Servo
  • 1x Transmitter and Reciever (requires at least 3 channels)
  • 1x 1500mAh 3s Lipo
  • 1x 5x4x3 Prop
  • 1x 4x4x3 Prop (or a trimmed down 5x4x3 will work)
  • 14x 3/8" long small diameter screws (about 3/32" dia. used for all screws) for thrust duct and lower hull
  • 16x 1/4" long small screws for lift duct and skirt ring
  • 10x 1/2" long small screws for rudders and front mount
  • 1x short piece of 1/8" Brass or Copper tube (1/2" rudder screws should be able to pass through bore)
  • 1x short piece of 1/32"/1mm music wire (spring steel) for pushrod
  • 1 Heavy duty trash bag for skirt

Tools Needed:

  • Small phillips or slotted screwdrivers (depending on what screws you use, I recommend button head coarse thread machine screws but they can be pricey)
  • Assortment of hex wrenches or drivers
  • Soldering iron
  • Handheld drill or rotary tool (Dremel)
  • 1/16" twist drill bit
  • Nut driver or socket for prop nuts
  • Xacto knife or razor blade of some sort
  • Flat needle files and/or sandpaper
  • Pliers

Printer:

Folgertech FT-5

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.3mm

Infill:

10-15%

Notes:

Print one of each part, and you'll need about 75 of the skirt clips to cover the entire perimeter of the upper hull. You don't necessarily need to use them all to secure the skirt but they do act as kind of a bumper to protect the edge of the hull.

I printed at 200 degrees onto build plate with build-tack at 55 degrees.

title: Yet another Raspberry PI case - V2

description.text:
Im planning to order another toy for me - Raspberry Pi. Since I like little bit another design Ive found here on Thingiverse, I redesigned great RP case made by RichRap. Featuring:
  • redesing
  • case now has stands! :)
  • removed mounting ears
  • GPIO/non GPIO version
  • completly new light guides. Dimensions of these guides are based on RichRap`s version.
    • V2 EDIT:
    Thanks to profbraino tips, version 2 comes to place.
  • Model is scaled now (1.02) so it is not so tight.
  • one board stand is moved, it should not interfere with board anymore (please confirm)
  • case was interfering with plastic under the usb connector. Problem solved.
  • gpio opening is 3 mm wider
    • I like idea to cover whole SD card, it just does not look nice right now. It is too big compared to rest of case. I have to figure out design for this feature. WARNING!
    I havent printed this case yet, because I do not have RP. Dimensions SHOULD be right, but it is not confirmed yet! Thats why is this thing marked as work in progress. If you will print it, please give me some feedback. Thank you.

• Read upper warning, if you are brave enough, continue
  • Choose bottom version (GPIO/non GPIO)
  • Print pair of legs, top and choosed bottom version
  • Take bottom version, clip printed pair of legs
  • Clip in your RP
  • Clip top
  • Watch how is your RP enjoying new home :)
  • Leave feedback!

title: Mercedes Benz W163 Trim Retainer Nut

description.text:
These nuts are used to retain the tailights in Mercedes Benz W163 ML series SUVs.

Over time the factory nuts come loose and the thread becomes worn and they no longer hold the tail lights correctly, resulting in wobbling lights, damaged bulb filaments, and large unsightly panel gaps

This replacement nut takes about 20 minutes to print with a 0.1mm layer height.

This is very similar to the interior carpet retainer nut used on many models on Mercedes Benz that era, so may be able to be used to retain carpet too.

I've designed this without an internal thread inside the nut. The factory retainer is threaded onto tapered self tapping thread fixed onto the vehicle. It should be forced onto the thread with a 10mm socket, so that the vehicle thread bites into the plastic to retain the nut. Make sure you clean the thread of old sealants or plastic for a good bite.

author: la_mecanique

print_settings.Notes:: It cost about 5 dollars of PLA filament with these settings. It was a rookie mistake to set the infill so high and I realize now I probably could have gotten away with a much lower infill setting.

description.text:
I made this for the Lansinoh breastmilk bags we were storing in the fridge. It allows us to see the expiration date easily and keep them organized.

I'm a beginner in both design and printing, so please look over the print notes to see where I messed up and what you'll need to do.

Please let me know if you have any suggestions for improvement. Thanks!

Edit 0: It was brought to my attention that a frozen milk bag that has frozen milk all the way up to the zipper will not fit. I've updated my design and included it as the v2 file. I haven't tested this build nor it's performance. This was not a use case I've encountered but would like to give someone the option to try it out. Please give me feedback if you have any. Thanks!

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

i3 MK2S

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Low (0.2 mm)

Infill:

60% (Probably waaaay too high)

Notes:

I printed mine with the back facing down so the arms and legs were pointing up. This way I was able to print without supports. I knew it wouldn't be the strongest orientation with the layers parallel to the load of the bags, but I haven't had any issues with it structurally.

I know the model I uploaded isn't oriented the way I described and I couldn't figure out how to fix it. A Y-axis rotation of 90 degrees in your slicer should do the trick. :)

With my print, I noticed the arms would flex slightly and the bags would slide out of the holder. This wasn't an issue after the holder was in the fridge for a while and became more rigid due to the colder temperatures.

It cost about 5 dollars of PLA filament with these settings. It was a rookie mistake to set the infill so high and I realize now I probably could have gotten away with a much lower infill setting.

Limit Switch / Homing Switch mount for open builds C-Beam End Mounts (http://openbuildspartstore.com/c-beam-end-mount/)

when slicing some of the thin walls can disappear (i.e. too narrow to print) and will not hur the capability of the mount to work as intended, you can see in my first photo where this has happened if you look closely.

Uses micro limit switches (https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B071NSRHK3/ref=oh_aui_search_detailpage?ie=UTF8&psc=1) Link are the exact ones i used seems to be a standard design spec.

I used supports carefully (i.e. don't put supports in the blind hole)

I have printed this with .4 and .8 nozzles and both work well enough.
